channel.title: (UK) 3 to actually provide actual *unlimited* download tariff?
channel.description:
http://www.pcpro.co.uk/news/broadband/363712/3-breaks-ranks-with-unlimited-mobile-data
Mobile operator 3 claims it intends to buck the trend of restricting data downloads with the introduction of what it calls “a truly unlimited data” package. According to 3, customers signing up to its One Plan will be allowed unrestricted data downloads, rather than the previous 1GB per month allowance. The announcement is significant because it comes at a time when most mobile companies are moving away from all-you-can-eat models, claiming consumer demand makes unlimited packages unviable. “Because we are a totally 3G network, it was made for broadband, which is why we can do this while other networks are introducing caps and limits,” a spokesperson for 3 told PC Pro. “The change is aimed at giving customers peace of mind when it comes to data.” Three told us that the new offer did not include a Fair Usage Policy, and would be available to all new customers as well as those already on the plan, which starts at £25. The offer is not yet appearing on the 3 website, but the company said the site would be updated later today to reflect the changes. The changes to the tariff follow a £400 million project to upgrade 3’s network, but only apply to smartphones on the One Plan contract. 3G dongle users will continue to face data caps. Read more: 3 breaks ranks with unlimited mobile data | Broadband | News | PC Pro http://www.pcpro.co.uk/news/broadband/363712/3-breaks-ranks-with-unlimited-mobile-data#ixzz18CZZIlog
This will likely pull me over to 3 when my contract runs out in June, of course, that coupled with their better 3G coverage, sounds good. Of course, we've had people saying they have an unlimited download tariff, but actually apply a fair usage policy, but 3 is saying no such policy will be in place here, and with their new network upgrades - they're confident in offering this.

item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

To be honest, as long as you get 10GB allowance I really don’t see the point in offering a “true unlimited” tariff just to make it sound better. If you do silly things like download 9999 films using your phone’s internet a month, you are truly a moron; just use your home connection!

Ideally all networks should offer theoretical unlimited data but closely monitor how much bandwidth you are using and if you are raping it consistently every month then you should receive a warning, followed by a disconnection if you do not comply.
